Expectation1: Provide emotional support and companionship to patients
Situation1: A patient has just received a difficult diagnosis and is visibly distressed and crying.
Expectation2: Provide clients with clear and accurate legal advice
Situation2: The client’s case grows more complex and requires detailed guidance
Story:
I sat beside Mrs. Thompson’s hospital bed, her hand trembling in mine as tears streamed down her face. She’d just learned her cancer had returned, and my heart ached to see her so broken. As a nursing assistant, I knew my place was here—offering comfort, listening, letting her know she wasn’t alone. But my phone buzzed insistently in my pocket. It was a message from my advocacy client, whose case had suddenly taken a complicated turn. He needed immediate, clear legal advice, and I was the only one he trusted to guide him through the maze of paperwork and deadlines.

I felt the weight of both worlds pressing down on me. Mrs. Thompson’s sobs grew softer, but her grip on my hand tightened, silently pleading for me to stay. At the same time, my client’s messages grew more urgent, each one a reminder of my responsibility to provide accurate, timely counsel. My mind raced, torn between the warmth of human connection and the cold precision of legal guidance. I could feel myself splitting in two, desperate not to fail either of them, yet knowing I couldn’t be fully present for both at once.
